review.title: Belief Revision, Minimal Change and Relaxation: A General Framework based on Satisfaction Systems, and Applications to Description Logics
review.abstract: Belief revision of knowledge bases represented by a set of sentences in a given logic has been extensively studied but for specific logics, mainly propositional, but also recently Horn and description logics. Here, we propose to generalize this operation from a model-theoretic point of view, by defining revision in a categorical abstract model theory known under the name of theory of institutions. In this framework, we generalize to any institution the characterization of the well known AGM postulates given by Katsuno and Mendelzon for propositional logic in terms of minimal change with respect to an ordering among interpretations. Moreover, we study how to define revision, satisfying the AGM postulates, from relaxation notions that have been first introduced in description logics to define dissimilarity measures between concepts, and the consequence of which is to relax the set of models of the old belief until it becomes consistent with the new pieces of knowledge. The proposed general framework can be instantiated in different logics such as propositional, description and Horn logics.

Here, we propose to generalize this operation from a model-theoretical point of view by defining revision in an abstract model theory known as satisfaction systems. In this context, we generalize to all satisfaction systems the characterization of the known AGM postulates introduced for the first time in descriptive logic by Katsuno and Mendelzon for the reasoning logic with respect to minimal changes between interpretations. Furthermore, we examine how to define revision by satisfying the AGM postulates, relaxation terms introduced in descriptive logic, in order to define similarities between concepts, and the consequence of which consists of loosening the set of knowledge models with the old ones until they are persuasive.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: The contribution of this paper is threefold: first, we provided a generalization of the AGM postulates from a model-theoretical point of view by defining this operator in an abstract model theory known as satisfaction systems, so that they become applicable to a broad class of non-classical logics. In this framework, we then generalized to all satisfaction systems the characterization of the AGM postulates given by Katsuno and Mendelzon for propositional logic with respect to minimal changes in an order between interpretations. This work generalizes the previous ones in this area. It also suggests that the theory behind satisfaction systems is a principle-driven framework for dealing with knowledge dynamics, with the growing interest in non-classical logic such as DL. We hope that bridges can be built in this way by working on the transverse of different areas of theoretical computer science in which logic is redefined. metadata.abstractText: Belief revision of knowledge bases represented by a set of sentences in a given logic has been extensively studied but for specific logics, mainly propositional, and also recently Horn and description logics. Here, we propose to generalize this operation from a modeltheoretic point of view, by defining revision in an abstract model theory known under the name of satisfaction systems. In this framework, we generalize to any satisfaction systems the characterization of the well known AGM postulates given by Katsuno and Mendelzon for propositional logic in terms of minimal change among interpretations. Moreover, we study how to define revision, satisfying the AGM postulates, from relaxation notions that have been first introduced in description logics to define dissimilarity measures between concepts, and the consequence of which is to relax the set of models of the old belief until it becomes consistent with the new pieces of knowledge. We show how the proposed general framework can be instantiated in different logics such as propositional, first-order, description and Horn logics. In particular for description logics, we introduce several concrete relaxation operators tailored for the description logic ALC and its fragments EL and ELU , discuss their properties and provide some illustrative examples.
